member.name: T:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Cell
member.summary:
Each cell is an object containing an actual value of the column type, plus an optional string-formatted version of the value that you provide.
For example: a numeric column might be assigned the value 7 and the formatted value "seven". If a formatted value is supplied, a chart will use the actual value for calculations and rendering, but might show the formatted value where appropriate, for example if the user hovers over a point. Each cell also has an optional map of arbitrary name/value pairs.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Cell.ColumnType
member.summary: Column type represents the type of value that the current cell holds.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Cell.Value
member.summary: [Optional] The cell value. The data ColumnType should match the column data ColumnType. If null, the whole object should be empty and have neither v nor f properties.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Cell.Formatted
member.summary: [Optional] A string version of the v value, formatted for display. The values should match, so if you specify Date(2008, 0, 1) for v, you should specify "January 1, 2008" or some such string for this property. This value is not checked against the v value. The visualization will not use this value for calculation, only as a label for display. If omitted, a string version of v will be used.

member.summary: Returns a list of currently assigned properties to the Cell

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Column.Id
member.summary: id [Optional] String ID of the column. Must be unique in the table. Use basic alphanumeric characters, so the host page does not require fancy escapes to access the column in JavaScript. Be careful not to choose a JavaScript keyword. Example: id:'col_1'

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Column.Label
member.summary: label [Optional] String value that some visualizations display for this column. Example: label:'Height'

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Column.ColumnType
member.summary: ColumnType [Required] Data ColumnType of the data in the column. Supports the following string values (examples include the v: property, described later):

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Column.Role
member.remarks: More info about the role can be read here https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/roles

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Column.Pattern
member.summary: pattern [Optional] String pattern that was used by a data source to format numeric, date, or time column values. This is for reference only; you probably won't need to read the pattern, and it isn't required to exist. The Google Visualization client does not use this value (it reads the cell's formatted value). If the DataTable has come from a data source in response to a query with a format clause, the pattern you specified in that clause will probably be returned in this value. The recommended pattern standards are the ICU DecimalFormat and SimpleDateFormat.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.Column.PropertyMap
member.summary:
p [Optional] An object that is a map of custom values applied to the cell. These values can be of any JavaScript ColumnType. If your visualization supports any cell-level properties, it will describe them; otherwise, this property will be ignored.
Example: p:{style: 'border: 1px solid green;'}.
member.remarks: Returns a list of currently assigned properties to the Cell

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Annotation
member.summary: Text to display on the chart near the associated data point. The text displays without any user interaction. Annotations and annotation text can be assigned to both data points and categories (axis labels).

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.AnnotationText
member.summary: Extended text to display when the user hovers over the associated annotation

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Certainty
member.summary: ndicates whether a data point is certain or not. How this is displayed depends on the chart typeâ€”for example, it might be indicated by dashed lines or a striped fill.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Emphasis
member.summary: Emphasizes specified chart data points. Displayed as a thick line and/or large point. For line and area charts, the segment between two data points is emphasized if and only if both data points are emphasized.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Interval
member.summary: ndicates potential data range for a specific point. Intervals are usually displayed as I-bar style range indicators. Interval columns are numeric columns; add interval columns in pairs, marking the low and high value of the bar. Interval values should be added in increasing value, from left to right.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Scope
member.summary: Indicates whether a point is in or out of scope. If a point is out of scope, it is visually de-emphasized. For line and area charts, the segment between two data points is in scope if either endpoint is in scope.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Tooltip
member.summary: Text to display when the user hovers over the data point associated with this row.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Domain
member.summary: You should not need to assign this role explicitly unless designing a multi-domain chart (shown here); the basic format of the data table enables the charting engine to infer which columns are domain columns. However, you should be aware of which columns are domain columns so that you know which other columns can modify it. Domain columns specify labels along the major axis of the chart. Multiple domain columns can sometimes be used to support multiple scales within the same chart.

member.name: P:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnRole.Data
member.summary:
You should not need to assign this role explicitly; the basic format of the data table enables the charting engine to infer which columns are domain columns. However, you sould be aware of which columns are data columns so that you know which other columns can modify it.
Data role columns specify series data to render in the chart. For most charts, one column = one series, but this can vary by chart type (for example, scatter charts require two data columns for the first series, and an additional one for each additional series; candlestick charts require four data columns for each series).

member.name: T:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.DataTable
member.summary:
A DataTable represents a basic two-dimensional table. All data (cells) in each column must have the same data type. Each cell in the table holds a value.
For more information about the usage of the serialized DataTable please visit: https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/reference#DataTable

member.name: T:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType
member.summary: ColumnType [Required] Data ColumnType of the data in the column. Supports the following string values (examples include the v: property, described later): 'boolean' - JavaScript boolean value ('true' or 'false'). Example value: v:'true' 'number' - JavaScript number value. Example values: v:7 , v:3.14, v:-55 'string' - JavaScript string value. Example value: v:'hello' 'date' - JavaScript Date object (zero-based month), with the time truncated. Example value: v:new Date(2008, 0, 15) 'datetime' - JavaScript Date object including the time. Example value: v:new Date(2008, 0, 15, 14, 30, 45) 'timeofday' - Array of three numbers and an optional fourth, representing hour (0 indicates midnight), minute, second, and optional millisecond. Example values: v:[8, 15, 0], v: [6, 12, 1, 144]

member.name: F:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType.String
member.summary: JavaScript string value. Example value: v:'hello'

member.name: F:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType.Number
member.summary: JavaScript number value. Example values: v:7 , v:3.14, v:-55

member.name: F:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType.Boolean
member.summary: JavaScript boolean value ('true' or 'false'). Example value: v:'true'

member.name: F:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType.Date
member.summary: JavaScript Date object (zero-based month), with the time truncated. Example value: v:new Date(2008, 0, 15)

member.name: F:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType.Datetime
member.summary: JavaScript Date object including the time. Example value: v:new Date(2008, 0, 15, 14, 30, 45)

member.name: F:Google.DataTable.Net.Wrapper.ColumnType.Timeofday
member.summary: Array of three numbers and an optional fourth, representing hour (0 indicates midnight), minute, second, and optional millisecond. Example values: v:[8, 15, 0], v: [6, 12, 1, 144]
